nodes.text: Economics can be reformulated using a quantum propensity framework: decision-makers are described by propensity functions expressible in quantum terms, yielding a quantized probabilistic model of economic transactions
Decision-makers should be modelled by a propensity function (probability of transacting) instead of a utility function
Use quantum circuits (unitary gates and entanglement via C-NOT) to generate propensity functions and simulate cognitive phenomena
A two-qubit quantum circuit with gates A and B and a C-NOT yields the same joint outcome probabilities as sequential measurements and thus reproduces the order effect probabilities

Quantum probability naturally models interference and entanglement and thereby can account for cognitive phenomena such as the order effect, disjunction effect, preference reversal, and social entanglement

Preference reversal exhibits a threshold criterion: a switch from the more attractive to the less attractive option occurs only if x2/x1 > 3; this criterion has been empirically tested and appears robust
A continuous propensity function can be represented as the squared amplitude of an underlying quantum wave function, mapping propensities to quantum states such as the quantum harmonic oscillator
An entropic force defined by f(x)=gamma P'(x)/P(x) follows from a propensity distribution; for a normal propensity this yields a linear spring-like force F(x) = -k(x-mu) with k = gamma / sigma^2
Mapping a normal propensity to a quantum harmonic oscillator gives mass m = hbar/(2 omega sigma^2) (mass inversely varies with variance) and a scaling gamma = hbar omega^2 with units of energy
The informational energy required for a typical preference reversal is approximately (hbar omega / 2) log(3), which is on the order of the base energy hbar omega / 2 of a quantum oscillator
Appendix demonstrates equivalence: one-qubit sequential-measurement representation and the two-qubit entangled circuit produce identical final outcome probabilities when A and B are unitary
The entropic-force plus quantum mapping provides consistent equations and units to describe dynamics of supply, demand, and financial transactions

Conclusion: the quantum propensity framework incorporates subjective and objective factors, explains cognitive interference and entanglement in decisions, and models economic transactions as quantized probabilistic systems useful for finance and economics
Limitation: quantifying human motivations, social power, or mental energy is contentious and human motivations cannot be fully reduced to exact equations
